document.masterDocTitle: Descriptions of two new genera, six new species and three new records of Anthozoa (Cnidaria) from the Sea of Marmara

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Descriptions of two new genera, six new species and three new records of Anthozoa (Cnidaria) from the Sea of Marmara

Figure 15.
Epizoanthus arenaceus
. (a) Preserved specimens showing the colony structure; (b) sphincter; (c) syphonoglyphs; (d) mesenteries with filaments and weak retractor muscles. Scale bars: a = 7.4 mm, b, c = 1 mm; d = 1.3 mm.

Figure 16.
Epizoanthus arenaceus
. Cnidom morphology in different parts of the body. (a) Spirocyst; (b) spirulae; (c) spirulae; (d) homotrich; (e) penicilli B; (f) spirulae; (g) spirulae; (h, i) homotrich; (j, k) spirulae; (l, m) homotrich; (n) penicilli A; (o) spirulae; (p, q) homotrich. Scale bar: 13 µm.

, 1 m, in a cave, 30 – 40 retracted specimens, Alborán Sea , O

. Ocaña leg; MMC-341,
4 September 2000
, Las Tres Piedras ( Benzú ), near vertical wall on a loose Stone on seaweeds bottom, 10 specimens attached on hard substrate, Bionomía project, Alborán Sea, O
. Ocaña leg
.

Small to medium sized zoantharian (in retracted condition, body
5 – 10 mm
wide); brownish colour along column, whitish patches on 12 – 15 scapular ridges located in capitulum border ( Figure 15 (a)). Ectodermis of column covered with sand and debris particules. Twenty-five to 35 tentacles arranged in four cycles; 25 – 28 mesenteries arranged in four cycles, last being incomplete. Pharynx lobulated, bearing a single siphonoglyph ( Figure 15 (c)). Single strong mesogloeal enlarged sphincter present ( Figure 15 (b)). Retractor absent, with a very weak parietobasilar development ( Figure 15 (d)). Basal coenenchyme forming a thin stolon with polyps arising together. Coenenchyme expanded.

Epizoanthus arenaceus
sp. nov. Frequency: vc: very common; c: common; rc: rather common; uc: uncommon; r: rare.

subSubSection.paragraph: A survey of the cnidom is summarized in Table 6 and Figure 16 .

In the Sea of Marmara , this species was found on shell fragments on sandy mud bottoms at
15 – 30 m
depths.
